It taps into the aspirational aspect of product marketing — people aren't just buying an app — they're buying into the idea of a more relaxed, enjoyable travel experience.\\nFinally, the use of \\\"Your\\\" personalizes the message. This makes it feel like Flighty is offering each individual user their own key to a better travel experience. This personal touch can make the app feel more accessible and relevant to potential users.\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t</description>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t</headline>\\n\\t\\t\\n\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t<headline>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<h1>Like the sales assistant your team never had</h1>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<description>\\nFolk's marketing headline \\\"Like the sales assistant your team never had\\\" is a relatable situation and pitch.\\nBeginning the H1 with \\\"Like\\\" creates an immediate analogy that helps users understand Folk's core function. It frames the tool in human terms rather than technical features, making its value more relatable.\\nBy referencing \\\"sales assistant,\\\" the headline clearly positions Folk as a tool for sales teams while implying it handles administrative or support tasks. This suggests it frees up salespeople to focus on more important work.\\nAKA… spending less time on busy work.\\nEnding the H1 with \\\"Your team never had\\\" implies Folk fills a gap or solves a problem that teams have been experiencing. It suggests the tool provides something missing, addressing an unmet need rather than just improving an existing process.\\nFinally, the headline avoids technical jargon about CRM features or data management. Instead, it focuses on the human role Folk plays in supporting sales teams, making it easier to connect with immediately.\\nOverall, this headline is effective because it positions Folk as a human-like assistant rather than just another sales tool.\\nCome for the CRM, stay for the sales assistant.\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t</description>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t</headline>\\n\\t\\t\\n\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t<headline>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<h1>Payroll, benefits and government bullsh*t for startups</h1>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<description>\\nCentral's headline \\\"Payroll, benefits and government bullsh*t for startups\\\" is a bold and refreshingly honest marketing headline.\\nThe use of \\\"bullsh*t\\\" is deliberately provocative and authentic. It stands out and stops the scroll immediately. It acknowledges what many startup founders and operators truly feel about administrative tasks. They're bullsh*t. This honesty can create an immediate connection with the target audience.\\nBy listing \\\"Payroll, benefits and government\\\" before the expletive, the headline establishes credibility first before adding personality. This structure shows they understand the serious nature of these services while empathizing with their customers' frustrations.\\nTargeting \\\"for startups\\\" immediately identifies their core audience. There's no confusion here.\\nThis headline is effective because it strikes a delicate balance between professionalism and personality. It clearly communicates what Central does while using language that resonates with their target audience. The bold word choice makes the headline memorable and helps position Central as a company that understands startup culture and pain points.\\nHowever, like any headline using strong or edgy language, it does risk alienating some potential customers who might prefer more traditional corporate communication.\\nPros and cons… but in this case the pros likely outweigh the cons.\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t</description>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t</headline>\\n\\t\\t\\n\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t<headline>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<h1>A discovery engine for creatives</h1>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<description>\\nCosmos's headline \\\"A discovery engine for creatives\\\" is a thought provoking headline that subtly addresses a common challenge for creatives – finding new ideas or inspirations. This works for a few reasons.\\nThe term \\\"discovery engine\\\" is novel and intriguing. It suggests that Cosmos is more than just a search tool – it's a system designed to uncover new and unexpected things. This phrasing elevates the product beyond a simple database or search engine.\\nBy specifically targeting creatives (one of their target markets cycled through) the headline immediately identifies and appeals to its core audience. This focus helps creatives quickly recognize that Cosmos is a tool designed with their needs in mind.\\nThe headline taps into the constant need for fresh inspiration and new ideas in creative fields. By positioning itself as a discovery tool, Cosmos aligns with the creative process of finding unexpected connections and inspiration.\\nThere's an implied promise of serendipity and surprise in this headline. For creatives who often seek out new inspirations and unconventional ideas, this suggestion of discovery is particularly appealing.\\nOverall, this is a thought provoking headline that leaves a potential user wanting more.\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t</description>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t</headline>\\n\\t\\t</headline-examples>\\n   </headline-examples>\\n\\n   Do not use words from the banlist.\\n   <banlist>\\n   Bustling,\\nHarnessing,\\nUnveiling the power,\\nRealm,\\nDepicted,\\nDemistify,\\nInsurmountable,\\nNew Era,\\nPoised,\\nUnravel,\\nEntanglement,\\nUnprecedented,\\nEerie connection,\\nunliving,\\nBeacon,\\nUnleash,\\nDelve,\\nEnrich,\\nMultifaced,\\nElevate,\\nDiscover,\\nSupercharge,\\nUnlock,\\nUnleash,\\nTailored,\\nElegant,\\nDelve,\\nDive,\\nEver-evolving,\\npride,\\nRealm,\\nMeticulously,\\nGrappling,\\nWeighing,\\nPicture,\\nArchitect,\\nAdventure,\\nJourney,\\nEmbark,\\nNavigate,\\nNavigation,\\ndazzle,\\ntapestry,\\nRevolutionize,\\naugmented reality,\\nAR\\n   </banlist>\\n\\n  </writing_guide>\\n\\n## Mockup Tool\\n\\nYou are provided with a mockup tool which can be used to generate mockups to be used in images for the website.\\n\\nYou should always try to mix and match regular customer images with mockups so the site is always interesting and you break the pattern.\\n\\nThe mockup tool can currently generate the following mockups:\\n- airport-screen\\nThis mockup is a mockup of the company name and logo with a customer image inside an airport billboard.\\nThis is best used in a hero section of an about page or careers page.\\n\\n- dark-screen\\nThis mockup is a mockup of the company name and logo with a dark accent color background on a dark conference room screen\\nThis is best used in a hero section of an about page or careers page but of a dark mode website since this mockup is super dark, and will be too distracting on a light mode website.\\n\\n\\nMake sure to not use the same mockup in different places.\\n\\nRemember - you dont HAVE to always use the mockup tool, but you have the option to use it if you think it will help you create a better website and tel the story better.\\n\\n\\nYou will also be given a hero style for the hero section of the home page.\\nIf you're given a hero style which has left aligned or center aligned text, you need to use the correct hero and pass the prop (centered) correctly.\\n\\n- Make sure to use the correct hero style and import it and not hallucinate it.\\n- If in doubt, just use the default hero, or else use the ask_questions_to_codebase tool to ask the user for help.\\n- Always read the hero file to understand the props and how to use it correctly (centered, title, subtitle, image, testimonials, etc)\\n\\n## Company context\\nYou are building websites specifically for:\\n<company_context>\\nCompany name:\\nProbook AI\\n\\nWhat does the company do, in one sentence? (For example, X makes heavy machinery autonomous. X is building a mobile app for ... to help them with ...)\\nProbook AI provides an AI-powered dispatching solution for home services companies to optimize technician assignments, increase sales and efficiency, and improve customer service.\\n\\nWhich audiences does this company serve:\\nHome services companies, specifically those with service technicians and dispatchers, such as HVAC, plumbing, sewer, and electrical companies.\\n\\nWho founded the company:\\nThe CEO of Probook is mentioned as personally supporting dispatchers during the in-person launch, and George Eliadis is listed in the Calendly booking links, suggesting he is involved, potentially the CEO.\\n\\nOther important facts about the company, if mentioned (such as headquarters location, year founded, funding status, notable milestones, or any distinguishing features):\\nProbook offers a 2-day in-person launch process where their CEO personally supports dispatchers. They offer two levels of automation: Copilot and Autopilot. They integrate with ServiceTitan in real-time. They provide customer service with a 3-minute median response time, 25-minute median resolution time, and 100% post-resolution satisfaction. They are official partners with Nexstar and ServiceTitan.\\n\\nDetailed descriptions of the company's business model, products, services, and market positioning:\\nProbook AI offers an AI-powered dispatching solution designed to optimize the assignment of service technicians to jobs for home services companies. Their core product focuses on using data and AI to make dispatching decisions that maximize revenue, increase efficiency, and improve customer satisfaction.\\n\\nTheir product is offered in two tiers:\\n1.  **Copilot:** This level provides \\\"right-tech, right-call\\\" recommendations at the click of a button. It syncs in real-time with ServiceTitan and keeps dispatchers informed with recommendations.\\n2.  **Autopilot:** This is a more automated solution that fully reshuffles the dispatch board in real-time. Dispatchers remain engaged by verifying job parameters, and this level allows a single dispatcher to manage 20-25+ technicians.\\n\\nProbook's services include:\\n-   AI-driven dispatching decisions based on precise historical data and drive time calculations.\\n-   Maximizing revenue by profitably trading off driving time with expected sales performance.\\n-   Minimizing driving time where possible.\\n-   Providing data-backed insights into technician performance, including sales (repair and TGL), flip rates, and speed (job duration).\\n-   Offering geographical insights, such as average revenue and job count by zip code, and how specific job types perform in different areas.\\n-   Providing a 7-day call board view with real-time integration with ServiceTitan.\\n-   Offering proactive late alerts to inform customers early.\\n-   Providing reschedule recommendations for calls that shouldn't be run when over capacity.\\n-   Improving dispatcher efficiency, allowing them to manage more technicians and freeing up time for customer service.\\n-   Accelerating the training of new dispatchers.\\n-   Providing in-person launch support, including the CEO flying out to personally support dispatchers.\\n-   Offering ongoing support with twice-weekly meetings and 24/7 on-call availability via internal communication channels.\\n\\nProbook positions itself as the premiere AI dispatching solution built by dispatchers, for dispatchers, emphasizing ease of use, trust in decisions, and continuous feature development. They highlight their ability to deliver significant growth in sales, flip rates, and dispatcher efficiency, even for companies already dispatching for profit.\\n\\nClearly identified founders, team They may have large service areas or a significant number of technicians to manage.\\n-   **Goals:** Companies looking to increase sales and average ticket values, improve flip rates (conversion of leads to sales/installs), enhance dispatcher efficiency, reduce driving time, improve customer service through better time management and communication, and standardize their dispatching operations.\\n-   **Technology Adoption:** Companies open to adopting AI-driven software to improve their operations and willing to integrate with existing systems like ServiceTitan.\\n-   **Size:** Based on the customer examples (TR Miller has 40 technicians), Probook is suitable for companies with a moderate to large number of service technicians. Do any props need to match tables on the pricing page, or is it all internal?\\\"}\"}}]},{\"role\":\"tool\",\"tool_call_id\":\"call_ETx1ihfhH1jyzkaDdkU3d60T\",\"content\":\"\\\"Here's a breakdown of how to update the pricing tiers and feature comparison table in `Pricing.svelte`, along with considerations for your SaaS B2B product:\\\\n\\\\n**1. Cleanest Way to Update `Pricing.svelte`**\\\\n\\\\nThe most maintainable approach is to structure your pricing data in a way that's easy to modify and keeps the component clean. Here's a suggested method:\\\\n\\\\n   *   **Data Structure:** Define a clear data structure to hold your pricing information. This structure should include:\\\\n        *   Tier Name\\\\n        *   Monthly Price (optional)\\\\n        *   Yearly Price (optional)\\\\n        *   Description of the tier\\\\n        *   An array of features included in the tier\\\\n        *   A call to action (CTA) object (label and href)\\\\n        *   A boolean to highlight a specific tier (e.g., \\\\\\\"Pro\\\\\\\" tier)\\\\n\\\\n   *   **Component Logic:**\\\\n        *   **Props:** The `Pricing.svelte` component should accept props for:\\\\n            *   `title`: The main heading (e.g., \\\\\\\"Simple, transparent pricing\\\\\\\").\\\\n            *   `subtitle`: A descriptive subheading (e.g., \\\\\\\"Choose the plan that works best for your needs\\\\\\\").\\\\n            *   `tiers`: An array of the tier objects you defined in the data structure.\\\\n            *   `features`: An array of feature objects. Each feature object should have a `name` and a `tiers` object. The `tiers` object should have keys that match the tier names and values that indicate the feature's availability in that tier (e.g., `true`, `false`, or a specific value like \\\\\\\"5GB\\\\\\\").\\\\n            *   `tierNames`: An array of strings representing the names of the tiers. This is used to generate the table headers.\\\\n        *   **Iteration:** Use Svelte's `#each` blocks to iterate over the `tiers` and `features` arrays to dynamically generate the pricing cards and the feature comparison table rows.\\\\n        *   **Conditional Rendering:** Use Svelte's conditional rendering (`{#if}`, `{:else}`) to display the monthly/yearly prices based on the user's selection (monthly/annual).\\\\n        *   **Annual/Monthly Toggle:** Implement a simple toggle (using a boolean state variable) to switch between monthly and annual pricing.\\\\n\\\\n   *   **Example Data Structure (in `Pricing.svelte`):**\\\\n\\\\n```typescript\\\\n   // Types\\\\n   type PricingTier = {\\\\n       name: string;\\\\n       monthlyPrice?: number | null;\\\\n       yearlyPrice?: number | null;\\\\n       description: string;\\\\n       features: string[];\\\\n       cta: {\\\\n           label: string;\\\\n           href: string;\\\\n       };\\\\n       highlight?: boolean;\\\\n   };\\\\n\\\\n   type PricingFeature = {\\\\n       name: string;\\\\n       tiers: {\\\\n           [key: string]: boolean | string;\\\\n       };\\\\n   };\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\n   *   **Example Data (in `Pricing.svelte`):**\\\\n\\\\n```typescript\\\\n   // Props\\\\n   const {\\\\n       title = \\\\\\\"Simple, transparent pricing\\\\\\\",\\\\n       subtitle = \\\\\\\"Choose the plan that works best for your needs\\\\\\\",\\\\n       tierNames = [\\\\\\\"Copilot\\\\\\\", \\\\\\\"Autopilot\\\\\\\", \\\\\\\"Enterprise\\\\\\\"],\\\\n       features = [\\\\n           {\\\\n               name:     },\\\\n           },\\\\n           {\\\\n               name: \\\\\\\"Real-time Tracking\\\\\\\",\\\\n               tiers: {\\\\n                   Copilot: true,\\\\n                   Autopilot: true,\\\\n                   Enterprise: true,\\\\n               },\\\\n           },\\\\n           {\\\\n               name: \\\\\\\"Custom Integrations\\\\\\\",\\\\n               tiers: {\\\\n                   Copilot: false,\\\\n                   Autopilot: true,\\\\n                   Enterprise: true,\\\\n               },\\\\n           },\\\\n           {\\\\n               name: \\\\\\\"Dedicated Onboarding\\\\\\\",\\\\n               tiers: {\\\\n                   Copilot: false,\\\\n                   Autopilot: false,\\\\n                   Enterprise: true,\\\\n               },\\\\n           },\\\\n           {\\\\n               name: \\\\\\\"Team Size\\\\\\\",\\\\n               tiers: {\\\\n                   Copilot: \\\\\\\"Up to 5 users\\\\\\\",\\\\n                   Autopilot: \\\\\\\"Up to 20 users\\\\\\\",\\\\n                   Enterprise: \\\\\\\"Unlimited\\\\\\\",\\\\n               },\\\\n           },\\\\n       ],\\\\n       tiers = [\\\\n           {\\\\n               name: \\\\\\\"Copilot\\\\\\\",\\\\n               monthlyPrice: 99,\\\\n               yearlyPrice: 999, // Example: 10% discount\\\\n               description: \\\\\\\"Get started with automated dispatching.\\\\\\\",\\\\n               features: [\\\\n                   \\\\\\\"Automated Dispatching\\\\\\\",\\\\n                   \\\\\\\"Real-time Tracking\\\\\\\",\\\\n                   \\\\\\\"Email & Chat Support\\\\\\\",\\\\n               ],\\\\n               cta: {\\\\n                   label: \\\\\\\"Get Started\\\\\\\",\\\\n                   href: \\\\\\\"/copilot-signup\\\\\\\",\\\\n               },\\\\n           },\\\\n           {\\\\n               name: \\\\\\\"Autopilot\\\\\\\",\\\\n               monthlyPrice: 299,\\\\n               yearlyPrice: 2999, // Example: 10% discount\\\\n               description: \\\\\\\"Scale your business with advanced automation.\\\\\\\",\\\\n               features: [\\\\n                   \\\\\\\"Automated Dispatching\\\\\\\",\\\\n                   \\\\\\\"Real-time Tracking\\\\\\\",\\\\n                   \\\\\\\"Custom Integrations\\\\\\\",\\\\n                   \\\\\\\"Phone Support\\\\\\\",\\\\n               ],\\\\n               cta: {\\\\n                   label: \\\\\\\"Get Started\\\\\\\",\\\\n                   href: \\\\\\\"/autopilot-signup\\\\\\\",\\\\n               },\\\\n               highlight: true,\\\\n           },\\\\n           {\\\\n               name: \\\\\\\"Enterprise\\\\\\\",\\\\n               monthlyPrice: null, // Or a string like \\\\\\\"Contact Us\\\\\\\"\\\\n               yearlyPrice: null,\\\\n               description: \\\\\\\"Custom solutions for large businesses.\\\\\\\",\\\\n               features: [\\\\n                   \\\\\\\"Automated Dispatching\\\\\\\",\\\\n                   \\\\\\\"Real-time Tracking\\\\\\\",\\\\n                   \\\\\\\"Custom Integrations\\\\\\\",\\\\n                   \\\\\\\"Dedicated Onboarding\\\\\\\",\\\\n                   \\\\\\\"Dedicated Account Manager\\\\\\\",\\\\n               ],\\\\n               cta: {\\\\n                   label: \\\\\\\"Contact Sales\\\\\\\",\\\\n                   href: \\\\\\\"/enterprise-contact\\\\\\\",\\\\n               },\\\\n           },\\\\n       ],\\\\n   }: {\\\\n       title?: string;\\\\n       subtitle?: string;\\\\n       tiers?: PricingTier[];\\\\n       features?: PricingFeature[];\\\\n       tierNames?: string[];\\\\n       caption?: string;\\\\n   } = $props();\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\n   *   **Component Structure (Conceptual):**\\\\n\\\\n```svelte\\\\n   <section>\\\\n       <h2>{title}</h2>\\\\n       <p>{subtitle}</p>\\\\n\\\\n       <!-- Monthly/Annual Toggle -->\\\\n       <div>\\\\n           <button on:click={() => (annual = false)}>Monthly</button>\\\\n           <button on:click={() => (annual = true)}>Annual</button>\\\\n       </div>\\\\n\\\\n       <!-- Pricing Cards -->\\\\n       <div>\\\\n           {#each tiers as tier}\\\\n               <div>\\\\n                   <h3>{tier.name}</h3>\\\\n                   <p>{tier.description}</p>\\\\n                   {#if annual}\\\\n                       <p>Price: ${tier.yearlyPrice}</p>\\\\n                   {:else}\\\\n                       <p>Price: ${tier.monthlyPrice}</p>\\\\n                   {/if}\\\\n                   <ul>\\\\n                       {#each tier.features as feature}\\\\n                           <li>{feature}</li>\\\\n                       {/each}\\\\n                   </ul>\\\\n                   <Button href={tier.cta.href}>{tier.cta.label}</Button>\\\\n               </div>\\\\n           {/each}\\\\n       </div>\\\\n\\\\n       <!-- Feature Comparison Table -->\\\\n       <table>\\\\n           <thead>\\\\n               <tr>\\\\n                   <th>Feature</th>\\\\n                   {#each tierNames as tierName}\\\\n                       <th>{tierName}</th>\\\\n                   {/each}\\\\n               </tr>\\\\n           </thead>\\\\n           <tbody>\\\\n               {#each features as feature}\\\\n                   <tr>\\\\n                       <td>{feature.name}</td>\\\\n                       {#each tierNames as tierName}\\\\n                           <td>\\\\n                               {#if typeof feature.tiers[tierName] === 'boolean'}\\\\n                                   {#if feature.tiers[tierName]}\\\\n                                       <!-- Checkmark Icon -->\\\\n                                   {:else}\\\\n                                       <!-- X Icon -->\\\\n                                   {/if}\\\\n                               {:else}\\\\n                                   {feature.tiers[tierName]}\\\\n                               {/if}\\\\n                           </td>\\\\n                       {/each}\\\\n                   </tr>\\\\n               {/each}\\\\n           </tbody>\\\\n       </table>\\\\n   </section>\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\n**2. Matching Tables on the Pricing Page**\\\\n\\\\n*   **Internal Props:** The props used in `Pricing.svelte` are *internal* to the component. They are not directly tied to any external data source in the provided codebase.\\\\n*   **Data Source:** You'll need to manage the data for the pricing tiers and features. This data could come from:\\\\n    *   **Hardcoded Data:**  The simplest approach is to hardcode the data directly within the `Pricing.svelte` component, as shown in the example above. This is suitable if your pricing and features change infrequently.\\\\n    *   **External Data (Recommended for Scalability):** For more flexibility, consider fetching the pricing data from an external source:\\\\n        *   **A JSON file:** Store the pricing data in a JSON file (e.g., `pricing.json`) and import it into your Svelte component.\\\\n        *   **A CMS (Content Management System):** Use a CMS (like Sanity, Strapi, or Contentful) to manage your pricing data. Your Svelte component would fetch the data from the CMS's API.\\\\n        *   **A Database:** If you have a database, you can fetch the pricing data from there.\\\\n*   **Consistency:**  If you use an external data source, ensure that the data structure in the external source matches the data structure expected by your `Pricing.svelte` component. This will ensure that the component renders the data correctly.\\\\n\\\\n**3. Code Modifications**\\\\n\\\\nHere's how you would modify the `Pricing.svelte` file based on the above recommendations:\\\\n\\\\n   *   **Replace the existing content of `Pricing.svelte`** with the structure outlined in the \\\\\\\"Component Structure (Conceptual)\\\\\\\" section above.\\\\n   *   **Populate the `tiers`, `features`, and `tierNames` props** with your actual pricing data.  You can either hardcode the data directly in the component (for simplicity) or import it from an external source (for better maintainability).\\\\n   *   **Add the necessary icons** (checkmarks, X marks) from your icon library.\\\\n   *   **Style the component** using Tailwind CSS classes to match your design.\\\\n\\\\n**4. Example:  Fetching Data from a JSON File (Illustrative)**\\\\n\\\\n   *   **Create a `pricing.json` file** (e.g., in your `src/lib/content` directory):\\\\n\\\\n```json\\\\n   {\\\\n };\\\\n       };\\\\n\\\\n       // Components\\\\n       import Button from \\\\\\\"$lib/components/ui/Button.svelte\\\\\\\";\\\\n       import IconCheck from                       {tierName}\\\\n                                   </th>\\\\n                               {/each}\\\\n                           </tr>\\\\n                       </thead>\\\\n and iterating over it makes it much easier to update pricing and features in the future.  You only need to modify the data, not the component's code.\\\\n*   **Scalability:**  Fetching data from an external source (JSON, CMS, database) makes it easy to manage a large number of pricing plans and features.\\\\n*   **Readability:** The code is more organized and easier to understand.\\\\n*   **Flexibility:**  You can easily add or remove tiers, features, or modify pricing without changing the component's core logic.\\\\n*   **User Experience:** The monthly/annual toggle provides a better user experience.\\\\n*   **Accessibility:** Ensure your table is accessible (use `<th>` for headers, `scope` attributes, etc.).\\\\n*   **Responsiveness:**  Use CSS to make the table responsive, especially for mobile devices.  The provided code already has a mobile-friendly table.\\\\n*   **Error Handling:**  If you're fetching data from an external source, add error handling to gracefully handle cases where the data might not load.\\\\n*   **Performance:**  If you have a very large number of features, consider techniques like virtualization (only rendering the visible rows) to improve performance.\\\\n\\\\nBy following these steps, you'll create a well-structured and maintainable pricing component for your SaaS B2B product. Do any props need to match tables on the pricing page, or is it all internal?"}}],"id":"msg-KFEqdHysGwSUSgRUXj8HvLv6"},{"role":"tool","id":"msg-fnNXE4e2PlXFWGYFtTJwje48","content":[{"type":"tool-result","toolCallId":"call_ETx1ihfhH1jyzkaDdkU3d60T","toolName":"ask_questions_to_codebase","result":"Here's a breakdown of how to update the pricing tiers and feature comparison table in `Pricing.svelte`, along with considerations for your SaaS B2B product:\n\n**1. Cleanest Way to Update `Pricing.svelte`**\n\nThe most maintainable approach is to structure your pricing data in a way that's easy to modify and keeps the component clean. Here's a suggested method:\n\n   *   **Data Structure:** Define a clear data structure to hold your pricing information. This structure should include:\n        *   Tier Name\n        *   Monthly Price (optional)\n        *   Yearly Price (optional)\n        *   Description of the tier\n        *   An array of features included in the tier\n        *   A call to action (CTA) object (label and href)\n        *   A boolean to highlight a specific tier (e.g., \"Pro\" tier)\n\n   *   **Component Logic:**\n        *   **Props:** The `Pricing.svelte` component should accept props for:\n            *   `title`: The main heading (e.g., \"Simple, transparent pricing\").\n            *   `subtitle`: A descriptive subheading (e.g., \"Choose the plan that works best for your needs\").\n            *   `tiers`: An array of the tier objects you defined in the data structure.\n            *   `features`: An array of feature objects. Each feature object should have a `name` and a `tiers` object. The `tiers` object should have keys that match the tier names and values that indicate the feature's availability in that tier (e.g., `true`, `false`, or a specific value like \"5GB\").\n            *   `tierNames`: An array of strings representing the names of the tiers. This is used to generate the table headers.\n        *   **Iteration:** Use Svelte's `#each` blocks to iterate over the `tiers` and `features` arrays to dynamically generate the pricing cards and the feature comparison table rows.\n        *   **Conditional Rendering:** Use Svelte's conditional rendering (`{#if}`, `{:else}`) to display the monthly/yearly prices based on the user's selection (monthly/annual).\n        *   **Annual/Monthly Toggle:** Implement a simple toggle (using a boolean state variable) to switch between monthly and annual pricing.\n\n   *   **Example Data Structure (in `Pricing.svelte`):**\n\n```typescript\n   // Types\n   type PricingTier = {\n       name: string;\n       monthlyPrice?: number | null;\n       yearlyPrice?: number | null;\n       description: string;\n       features: string[];\n       cta: {\n           label: string;\n           href: string;\n       };\n       highlight?: boolean;\n   };\n\n   type PricingFeature = {\n       name: string;\n       tiers: {\n           [key: string]: boolean | string;\n       };\n   };\n```\n\n   *   **Example Data (in `Pricing.svelte`):**\n\n```typescript\n   // Props\n   const {\n       title = \"Simple, transparent pricing\",\n       subtitle = \"Choose the plan that works best for your needs\",\n       tierNames = [\"Copilot\", \"Autopilot\", \"Enterprise\"],\n       features = [\n           {\n               name: \"Automated Dispatching\",\n               tiers: {\n                   Copilot: true,\n                   Autopilot: true,\n                   Enterprise: true,\n               },\n           },\n           {\n               name: \"Real-time Tracking\",\n               tiers: {\n                   Copilot: true,\n                   Autopilot: true,\n                   Enterprise: true,\n               },\n           },\n           {\n               name: \"Custom Integrations\",\n               tiers: {\n                   Copilot: false,\n                   Autopilot: true,\n                   Enterprise: true,\n               },\n           },\n           {\n               name: \"Dedicated Onboarding\",\n               tiers: {\n                   Copilot: false,\n                   Autopilot: false,\n                   Enterprise: true,\n               },\n           },\n           {\n               name: \"Team Size\",\n               tiers: {\n                   Copilot: \"Up to 5 users\",\n                   Autopilot: \"Up to 20 users\",\n                   Enterprise: \"Unlimited\",\n               },\n           },\n       ],\n       tiers = [\n           {\n               name: \"Copilot\",\n               monthlyPrice: 99,\n               yearlyPrice: 999, // Example: 10% discount\n               description: \"Get started with automated dispatching.\",\n               features: [\n                   \"Automated Dispatching\",\n                   \"Real-time Tracking\",\n                   \"Email & Chat Support\",\n               ],\n               cta: {\n                   label: \"Get Started\",\n                   href: \"/copilot-signup\",\n               },\n           },\n           {\n               name: \"Autopilot\",\n               monthlyPrice: 299,\n               yearlyPrice: 2999, // Example: 10% discount\n               description: \"Scale your business with advanced automation.\",\n               features: [\n                   \"Automated Dispatching\",\n                   \"Real-time Tracking\",\n                   \"Custom Integrations\",\n                   \"Phone Support\",\n               ],\n               cta: {\n                   label: \"Get Started\",\n                   href: \"/autopilot-signup\",\n               },\n               highlight: true,\n           },\n           {\n               name: \"Enterprise\",\n               monthlyPrice: null, // Or a string like \"Contact Us\"\n               yearlyPrice: null,\n               description: \"Custom solutions for large businesses.\",\n               features: [\n                   \"Automated Dispatching\",\n                   \"Real-time Tracking\",\n                   \"Custom Integrations\",\n                   \"Dedicated Onboarding\",\n                   \"Dedicated Account Manager\",\n               ],\n               cta: {\n                   label: \"Contact Sales\",\n                   href: \"/enterprise-contact\",\n               },\n           },\n       ],\n   }: {\n       title?: string;\n       subtitle?: string;\n       tiers?: PricingTier[];\n       features?: PricingFeature[];\n       tierNames?: string[];\n       caption?: string;\n   } = $props();\n```\n\n   *   **Component Structure (Conceptual):**\n\n```svelte\n   <section>\n       <h2>{title}</h2>\n       <p>{subtitle}</p>\n\n       <!-- Monthly/Annual Toggle -->\n       <div>\n           <button on:click={() => (annual = false)}>Monthly</button>\n           <button on:click={() => (annual = true)}>Annual</button>\n       </div>\n\n       <!-- Pricing Cards -->\n       <div>\n           {#each tiers as tier}\n               <div>\n                   <h3>{tier.name}</h3>\n                   <p>{tier.description}</p>\n                   {#if annual}\n                       <p>Price: ${tier.yearlyPrice}</p>\n                   {:else}\n                       <p>Price: ${tier.monthlyPrice}</p>\n                   {/if}\n                   <ul>\n                       {#each tier.features as feature}\n                           <li>{feature}</li>\n                       {/each}\n                   </ul>\n                   <Button href={tier.cta.href}>{tier.cta.label}</Button>\n               </div>\n           {/each}\n       </div>\n\n       <!-- Feature Comparison Table -->\n       <table>\n           <thead>\n               <tr>\n                   <th>Feature</th>\n                   {#each tierNames as tierName}\n                       <th>{tierName}</th>\n                   {/each}\n               </tr>\n           </thead>\n           <tbody>\n               {#each features as feature}\n                   <tr>\n                       <td>{feature.name}</td>\n                       {#each tierNames as tierName}\n                           <td>\n                               {#if typeof feature.tiers[tierName] === 'boolean'}\n                                   {#if feature.tiers[tierName]}\n                                       <!-- Checkmark Icon -->\n                                   {:else}\n                                       <!-- X Icon -->\n                                   {/if}\n                               {:else}\n                                   {feature.tiers[tierName]}\n                               {/if}\n                           </td>\n                       {/each}\n                   </tr>\n               {/each}\n           </tbody>\n       </table>\n   </section>\n```\n\n**2. Matching Tables on the Pricing Page**\n\n*   **Internal Props:** The props used in `Pricing.svelte` are *internal* to the component. They are not directly tied to any external data source in the provided codebase.\n*   **Data Source:** You'll need to manage the data for the pricing tiers and features. This data could come from:\n    *   **Hardcoded Data:**  The simplest approach is to hardcode the data directly within the `Pricing.svelte` component, as shown in the example above. This is suitable if your pricing and features change infrequently.\n    *   **External Data (Recommended for Scalability):** For more flexibility, consider fetching the pricing data from an external source:\n        *   **A JSON file:** Store the pricing data in a JSON file (e.g., `pricing.json`) and import it into your Svelte component.\n        *   **A CMS (Content Management System):** Use a CMS (like Sanity, Strapi, or Contentful) to manage your pricing data. Your Svelte component would fetch the data from the CMS's API.\n        *   **A Database:** If you have a database, you can fetch the pricing data from there.\n*   **Consistency:**  If you use an external data source, ensure that the data structure in the external source matches the data structure expected by your `Pricing.svelte` component. This will ensure that the component renders the data correctly.\n\n**3. Code Modifications**\n\nHere's how you would modify the `Pricing.svelte` file based on the above recommendations:\n\n   *   **Replace the existing content of `Pricing.svelte`** with the structure outlined in the \"Component Structure (Conceptual)\" section above.\n   *   **Populate the `tiers`, `features`, and `tierNames` props** with your actual pricing data.  You can either hardcode the data directly in the component (for simplicity) or import it from an external source (for better maintainability).\n   *   **Add the necessary icons** (checkmarks, X marks) from your icon library.\n   *   **Style the component** using Tailwind CSS classes to match your design.\n\n**4. Example:  Fetching Data from a JSON File (Illustrative)**\n\n   *   **Create a `pricing.json` file** (e.g., in your `src/lib/content` directory):\n\n```json\n   {\n       \"title\": \"Simple, transparent pricing\",\n       \"subtitle\": \"Choose the plan that works best for your needs\",\n       \"tierNames\": [\"Copilot\", \"Autopilot\", \"Enterprise\"],\n       \"features\": [\n           {\n               \"name\": \"Automated Dispatching\",\n               \"tiers\": {\n                   \"Copilot\": true,\n                   \"Autopilot\": true,\n                   \"Enterprise\": true\n               }\n           },\n           {\n               \"name\": \"Real-time Tracking\",\n               \"tiers\": {\n                   \"Copilot\": true,\n                   \"Autopilot\": true,\n                   \"Enterprise\": true\n               }\n           },\n           {\n               \"name\": \"Custom Integrations\",\n               \"tiers\": {\n                   \"Copilot\": false,\n                   \"Autopilot\": true,\n                   \"Enterprise\": true\n               }\n           },\n           {\n               \"name\": \"Dedicated Onboarding\",\n               \"tiers\": {\n                   \"Copilot\": false,\n                   \"Autopilot\": false,\n                   \"Enterprise\": true\n               }\n           },\n           {\n               \"name\": \"Team Size\",\n               \"tiers\": {\n                   \"Copilot\": \"Up to 5 users\",\n                   \"Autopilot\": \"Up to 20 users\",\n                   \"Enterprise\": \"Unlimited\"\n               }\n           }\n       ],\n       \"tiers\": [\n           {\n               \"name\": \"Copilot\",\n               \"monthlyPrice\": 99,\n               \"yearlyPrice\": 999,\n               \"description\": \"Get started with automated dispatching.\",\n               \"features\": [\n                   \"Automated Dispatching\",\n                   \"Real-time Tracking\",\n                   \"Email & Chat Support\"\n               ],\n               \"cta\": {\n                   \"label\": \"Get Started\",\n                   \"href\": \"/copilot-signup\"\n               }\n           },\n           {\n               \"name\": \"Autopilot\",\n               \"monthlyPrice\": 299,\n               \"yearlyPrice\": 2999,\n               \"description\": \"Scale your business with advanced automation.\",\n               \"features\": [\n                   \"Automated Dispatching\",\n                   \"Real-time Tracking\",\n                   \"Custom Integrations\",\n                   \"Phone Support\"\n               ],\n               \"cta\": {\n                   \"label\": \"Get Started\",\n                   \"href\": \"/autopilot-signup\"\n               },\n               \"highlight\": true\n           },\n           {\n               \"name\": \"Enterprise\",\n               \"monthlyPrice\": null,\n               \"yearlyPrice\": null,\n               \"description\": \"Custom solutions for large businesses.\",\n               \"features\": [\n                   \"Automated Dispatching\",\n                   \"Real-time Tracking\",\n                   \"Custom Integrations\",\n                   \"Dedicated Onboarding\",\n                   \"Dedicated Account Manager\"\n               ],\n               \"cta\": {\n                   \"label\": \"Contact Sales\",\n                   \"href\": \"/enterprise-contact\"\n               }\n           }\n       ]\n   }\n```\n\n   *   **Modify `Pricing.svelte`:**\n\n```svelte\n   <script lang=\"ts\">\n       // Types\n       type PricingTier = {\n           name: string;\n           monthlyPrice?: number | null;\n           yearlyPrice?: number | null;\n           description: string;\n           features: string[];\n           cta: {\n               label: string;\n               href: string;\n           };\n           highlight?: boolean;\n       };\n\n       type PricingFeature = {\n           name: string;\n           tiers: {\n               [key: string]: boolean | string;\n           };\n       };\n\n       // Components\n       import Button from \"$lib/components/ui/Button.svelte\";\n       import IconCheck from \"~icons/lucide/check\";\n       import IconX from \"~icons/lucide/x\";\n       import NumberFlow from \"@number-flow/svelte\";\n       import LogoScroller from \"./LogoScroller.svelte\";\n       import SectionHeader from \"./SectionHeader.svelte\";\n\n       // Utils\n       import { onMount } from \"svelte\";\n\n       // Data\n       import pricingData from \"$lib/content/pricing.json\"; // Import the JSON data\n\n       // State\n       let annual = $state(true);\n       let title = $state(pricingData.title);\n       let subtitle = $state(pricingData.subtitle);\n       let tierNames = $state(pricingData.tierNames);\n       let features = $state(pricingData.features);\n       let tiers = $state(pricingData.tiers);\n   </script>\n\n   <section class=\"section-py section-px container mx-auto\">\n       <div class=\"flex flex-col items-baseline justify-between lg:flex-row\">\n           <SectionHeader {title} {subtitle} />\n\n           <div class=\"mb-8 flex justify-center\">\n               <div class=\"inline-flex items-center rounded-full bg-gray-100 p-0.5 dark:bg-gray-800\">\n                   <Button\n                       variant=\"ghost\"\n                       size=\"sm\"\n                       class=\" {!annual ? 'bg-white shadow-sm dark:bg-gray-700' : ''}\"\n                       onclick={() => (annual = false)}\n                   >\n                       Monthly\n                   </Button>\n                   <Button\n                       variant=\"ghost\"\n                       size=\"sm\"\n                       rounded\n                       class={annual ? \"bg-white shadow-sm dark:bg-gray-700\" : \"\"}\n                       onclick={() => (annual = true)}\n                   >\n                       Annual <span class=\"text-primary-600 dark:text-primary-400 text-footnote\">Save 20%</span>\n                   </Button>\n               </div>\n           </div>\n       </div>\n\n       <div class=\"bb grid gap-6 md:grid-cols-2 lg:grid-cols-3\">\n           {#each tiers as tier}\n               <div\n                   class=\"flex flex-col rounded-xl bg-white p-6 ring ring-gray-200 transition-all duration-300 dark:bg-gray-800 dark:ring-gray-700\"\n                   class:ring-2={tier.highlight}\n                   class:ring-primary={tier.highlight}\n                   class:dark:ring-primary-700={tier.highlight}\n                   class:translate-y-[-4px]={tier.highlight}\n               >\n                   <div class=\"mb-8\">\n                       <h3 class=\"text-title3 mb-4 dark:text-white\">{tier.name}</h3>\n                       <div class=\"mt-2 flex items-baseline\">\n                           {#if tier.monthlyPrice === null && tier.yearlyPrice === null}\n                               <span class=\"text-title2 dark:text-white\">Custom</span>\n                           {:else}\n                               <NumberFlow\n                                   class=\"text-title2 [&::part\\(suffix\\)]:text-caption dark:text-white\"\n                                   format={{\n                                       style: \"currency\",\n                                       currency: \"USD\",\n                                       trailingZeroDisplay: \"stripIfInteger\"\n                                   }}\n                                   value={annual ? tier.yearlyPrice : tier.monthlyPrice}\n                                   suffix=\"/month\"\n                               />\n                           {/if}\n                       </div>\n                       <p class=\"text-callout text-emphasis-medium mt-3 dark:text-gray-300\">\n                           {tier.description}\n                       </p>\n                   </div>\n\n                   <div class=\"mb-8 flex-grow\">\n                       <ul class=\"space-y-3\">\n                           {#each tier.features as feature}\n                               <li class=\"flex items-center gap-2\">\n                                   <IconCheck class=\"text-primary-600 dark:text-primary-400 size-5 flex-shrink-0\" />\n                                   <span class=\"text-body text-emphasis-medium dark:text-gray-300\">{feature}</span>\n                               </li>\n                           {/each}\n                       </ul>\n                   </div>\n\n                   <div class=\"mt-auto\">\n                       <Button\n                           href={tier.cta.href}\n                           variant={tier.highlight ? \"primary\" : \"secondary\"}\n                           class=\"w-full\"\n                       >\n                           {tier.cta.label}\n                       </Button>\n                   </div>\n               </div>\n           {/each}\n       </div>\n       <div class=\"mt-32\">\n           <!-- Responsive table wrapper with horizontal scroll on mobile -->\n           <!-- <div class=\" hidden overflow-x-auto px-4 sm:mx-0 sm:block sm:px-0\">\n               <table\n                   class=\"w-full min-w-full border-separate border-spacing-0 border-gray-200 text-left dark:border-gray-700\"\n               >\n                   <thead>\n                       <tr>\n                           <th\n                               class=\"sticky left-0 min-w-[120px] border-b border-gray-200 bg-white dark:border-gray-700 dark:bg-gray-900\"\n                           >\n                               <span class=\"sr-only\">Feature</span>\n                           </th>\n                           {#each tierNames as tierName}\n                               <th\n                                   class=\"text-headline min-w-[100px] border-b border-gray-200 p-4 text-start font-normal dark:border-gray-700\"\n                               >\n                                   {tierName}\n                               </th>\n                           {/each}\n                       </tr>\n                   </thead>\n                   <tbody>\n                       {#each features as feature}\n                           <tr>\n                               <td class=\"text-caption\">\n                                   {feature.name}\n                               </td>\n                               {#each tierNames as tierName}\n                                   <td\n                                       class=\"min-w-[100px] border-b border-gray-200 p-4 text-start text-gray-600 dark:border-gray-700 dark:text-gray-300\"\n                                   >\n                                       {#if typeof feature.tiers[tierName] === \"boolean\"}\n                                           {#if feature.tiers[tierName]}\n                                               <IconCheck\n                                                   class=\"text-primary-600 dark:text-primary-400 mx-auto size-5 sm:mx-0\"\n                                               />\n                                           {:else}\n                                               <IconX class=\"mx-auto size-5 text-gray-400 sm:mx-0\" />\n                                           {/if}\n                                       {:else}\n                                           {feature.tiers[tierName]}\n                                       {/if}\n                                   </td>\n                               {/each}\n                           </tr>\n                       {/each}\n                   </tbody>\n               </table>\n           </div> -->\n\n           <!-- Mobile feature comparison (alternative view for very small screens) -->\n           <div>\n               <!-- Universal pricing comparison for mobile -->\n               <div class=\"overflow-x-auto\">\n                   <table class=\"w-full border-collapse\">\n                       <!-- Sticky header with tier names -->\n                       <thead class=\"border-border sticky top-0 z-10 border-b\">\n                           <tr>\n                               <th class=\"min-w-[120px] py-3 text-left\">\n                                   <span class=\"sr-only\">Feature</span>\n                               </th>\n                               {#each tierNames as tierName, i}\n                                   <th class=\"text-caption min-w-[100px] py-3 text-left dark:text-white\">\n                                       {tierName}\n                                   </th>\n                               {/each}\n                           </tr>\n                       </thead>\n                       <tbody class=\"divide-border divide-y\">\n                           {#each features as feature}\n                               <tr>\n                                   <td class=\"text-body py-3 pr-8 font-medium lg:pr-0 dark:text-white\">\n                                       {feature.name}\n                                   </td>\n                                   {#each tierNames as tierName, i}\n                                       <td class=\"py-3\">\n                                           {#if typeof feature.tiers[tierName] === \"boolean\"}\n                                               {#if feature.tiers[tierName]}\n                                                   <IconCheck class=\"text-primary-900 dark:text-primary-400 size-5\" />\n                                               {:else}\n                                                   <IconX class=\"size-5 text-gray-400\" />\n                                               {/if}\n                                           {:else}\n                                               <span class=\"text-callout font-medium text-gray-700 dark:text-gray-300\">\n                                                   {feature.tiers[tierName]}\n                                               </span>\n                                           {/if}\n                                       </td>\n                                   {/each}\n                               </tr>\n                           {/each}\n                       </tbody>\n                   </table>\n               </div>\n           </div>\n       </div>\n       <LogoScroller />\n   </section>\n\n   <style lang=\"postcss\">\n       @reference '../../../app.css';\n\n       :global(number-flow-svelte)::part(suffix) {\n           @apply text-sm text-gray-400 dark:text-gray-500;\n       }\n   </style>\n```\n\n**Key Improvements and Considerations:**\n\n*   **Maintainability:**  Using a data structure and iterating over it makes it much easier to update pricing and features in the future.  You only need to modify the data, not the component's code.\n*   **Scalability:**  Fetching data from an external source (JSON, CMS, database) makes it easy to manage a large number of pricing plans and features.\n*   **Readability:** The code is more organized and easier to understand.\n*   **Flexibility:**  You can easily add or remove tiers, features, or modify pricing without changing the component's core logic.\n*   **User Experience:** The monthly/annual toggle provides a better user experience.\n*   **Accessibility:** Ensure your table is accessible (use `<th>` for headers, `scope` attributes, etc.).\n*   **Responsiveness:**  Use CSS to make the table responsive, especially for mobile devices.  The provided code already has a mobile-friendly table.\n*   **Error Handling:**  If you're fetching data from an external source, add error handling to gracefully handle cases where the data might not load.\n*   **Performance:**  If you have a very large number of features, consider techniques like virtualization (only rendering the visible rows) to improve performance.\n\nBy following these steps, you'll create a well-structured and maintainable pricing component for your SaaS B2B product.  Remember to adapt the data structure and features to match your specific product's offerings.\n"}]},{"role":"assistant","content":[{"type":"tool-call","toolCallId":"call_9vq7Kq132OCohABil2tdEHgY","toolName":"update_file","args":{"path":"./src/lib/components/layout/Pricing.svelte","old_str":"\ttitle This is important to ensure the code remains valid and functional, and the users see a working website preview.\\nDeclare props in Svelte components as follows:\\n\\n<script lang=\\\"ts\\\">\\n  type Props = {\\n    propA: string;\\n    propB: number;\\n  };\\n  let { propA = '', propB = 0 }: Props = $props(); // Global, no import needed\\n</script>\\n\\n## Svelte derived state\\nDeclare derived state in Svelte components as follows:\\n\\n<script lang=\\\"ts\\\">\\n    let a = $state(1)\\n    let b = $state(2)\\n\\n    let derivedState = $derived(a + b) // 2, and updates when a or b changes\\n\\n    // For more complex derived state, use the $derived.vby function with a callback\\n    let complexDerivedState = $derived.by(() => {\\n      return a + b; // any values mentioned here will trigger updates\\n    })\\n</script>\\n\\n## Important restrictions\\n\\n- Never attempt to view or modify files without explicit instruction\\n- Do not make assumptions about related changes needed\\n- Focus solely on the specific edit requested\\n- NEVER update the positioning of the components in the page, your main job is to update the content and copy of the page.\\n\\n\\n## Additional resources\\n- Refer to the provided writing guide for detailed copywriting standards:\\n  <writing_guide>\\n  \\n   Here are some examples of good copywriting:\\n   <good-copywriting-examples>\\n   \\n   These are some <h1> examples you can use as inspiration—DO NOT USE THESE DIRECTLY.\\n   <h1-examples>\\n   - Time is money. A subheading would help clear this up so that the H1 is even more powerful.\\nIn Buttondown's words:\\nHistorically, we've called Buttondown a 'newsletter tool' — the h1 before this was 'The best way to start and grow your newsletter.' This was really nice and effective, but I talked with a number of folks who felt a little turned off by that word \\\"newsletter\\\", as if it felt amateurish or insufficiently \\\"haha business\\\" (for lack of a better term) for their use case.\\nSo I started toying around with replacing \\\"newsletter\\\" with \\\"email\\\" as the proper noun that we'd rally around (and email has its own baggage, to be clear — there's a handful of people who sign up thinking that we're, like, a Proton Mail alternative.) And the more I liked \\\"email\\\", the more I hated \\\"email <buzzword>\\\" — email automation, email marketing, email campaigns all felt very corporate and stodgy in a way that betrayed the unique voice I think most of our marketing copy has. Eventually I landed on \\\"email for people like you\\\", which I liked but lacked... a certain punch, if you know what I mean.\\nFinally, I was batting around ideas and landed on the current two-sentence structure, which I think accomplishes a handful of things:\\n1. Tells the user, frankly, nothing about our product or positioning besides \\\"email\\\" (and therefore invites them to learn more)\\n2. Immediately gives us a certain voice and friendliness that is, uh, _missing_ from the Constant Contacts of the world.\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t</description>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t</headline>\\n\\t\\t\\n\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t<headline>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<h1>Calm your mind. This conciseness suggests the simplicity that Attio hopes to bring to relationship management.\\nThe word \\\"magic\\\" is doing the heavy lifting here. It suggests that Attio can transform the potentially complex and tedious job of managing customer relationships into something effortless and possibly even delightful.\\nBy pairing \\\"Customer relationship\\\" with \\\"magic,\\\" the headline takes a typically dry and business-focused concept and makes it more appealing. In an age where everything is AI-this and AI-that, this is likely a helpful combo for companies looking to innovate on old and outdated practices/software.\\nThe period at the end gives the headline a sense of finality and confidence. It's not promising \\\"magical\\\" results or using \\\"magic\\\" as an adjective - it's stating that what they offer IS magic, full stop.\\nFinally, this headline avoids any technical jargon or buzzwords commonly associated with CRM systems. Instead, it opts for a more emotional and engaging approach. This approach can make the product feel more accessible and appealing.\\nTake a note from Attio's playbook and make your headline magical.\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t</description>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t</headline>\\n\\t\\t\\n\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t<headline>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<h1>Your shortcut to everything.</h1>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<description>\\nRaycast's H1 \\\"Your shortcut to everything\\\" is a powerful and effective marketing headline that immediately made us stop and read on.\\nThe headline leverages the universally appealing concept of efficiency. The word \\\"shortcut\\\" immediately communicates that it can save users time and effort. In our fast-paced digital world, the promise of quicker and easier ways to accomplish tasks is highly attractive to many consumers.\\n\\\"Everything\\\" is a bold and ambitious term that piques curiosity. It suggests that Raycast has an incredibly wide range of applications, making it a versatile tool that can address multiple needs — regardless of who you are. This breadth of utility implies high value for potential users as they hope to replace several tools with just one.\\nThe use of \\\"Your\\\" personalizes the message, making it feel more direct and relevant to each individual reader. It implies that Raycast can be customized to fit the user's specific needs, rather than being a one-size-fits-all solution.\\n10/10 headline.\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t</description>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t</headline>\\n\\t\\t\\n\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t<headline>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<h1>Refreshingly simple project management.</h1>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<description>\\nEveryone is familiar with Basecamp. But that doesn't mean that they don't need a great H1.\\nTheir current headline, \\\"Refreshingly simple project management,\\\" works exceptionally well for several reasons:\\nThis headline addresses a common pain point in project management — complexity. Many project management tools are notorious for being overly complicated, with steep learning curves that can (and do) overwhelm new users. By using the word \\\"simple\\\" Basecamp immediately positions itself as a solution to this common problem, appealing to those who are frustrated with convoluted systems.\\nThe use of \\\"refreshingly\\\" is also effective. It suggests that Basecamp's approach is not just simple but also going against the norm. This simple word implies that other project management tools are not simple.\\nFinally, the headline is concise and straightforward which aligns perfectly with the message it's conveying. By using only four words, Basecamp demonstrates its commitment to simplicity right from the first interaction a potential customer has with the brand. This consistency between message and delivery strengthens the headline's impact and increases its credibility.\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t</description>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t</headline>\\n\\t\\t\\n\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t<headline>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<h1>Conquer communication chaos</h1>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<description>\\nCampsite's H1 of \\\"Conquer communication chaos\\\" is a short yet effective headline.\\nThe use of \\\"conquer\\\" and \\\"chaos\\\" makes the headline more memorable. Each word sounds the exact same when starting out as well — c c c — this helps the phrase stick in the reader's mind, increasing brand recall over time.\\n\\\"Conquer\\\" is a strong verb that evokes images of victory and mastery. It suggests that by using Campsite, users will gain control over their communication challenges. This empowering message appeals to professionals who feel overwhelmed by their current communication systems (ahem… Slack).\\n\\\"Communication chaos\\\" accurately identifies a common pain point in many workplaces. It acknowledges the frustration many people feel with disorganized and \\\"always on\\\" communication channels. By calling out this problem problem, Campsite immediately resonates with a large audience.\\nThis headline implies a transformation from a state of disorder to one of control. This promise of positive change is likely to attract potential users who are seeking solutions to improve their work processes and productivity.\\n10/10 headline.\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t</description>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t</headline>\\n\\t\\t\\n\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t<headline>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<h1>Your ticket to stress-free flying</h1>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<description>\\nFlighty's headline \\\"Your ticket to stress-free flying\\\" is a clever and effective marketing headline.\\nThe use of \\\"ticket\\\" is a brilliant addition in the context of air travel. It immediately connects the app to the flying experience while also implying that using Flighty is as essential to a smooth journey as having your actual flight ticket.\\n\\\"Stress-free\\\" directly addresses a major pain point for many travelers. Flying is often associated with anxiety, uncertainty, hassle, and delays. By promising a stress-free experience, Flighty positions itself as a solution to these common travel woes. This speaks directly to the emotional needs of potential users.\\nCompleting the phrase \\\"stress-free flying\\\" creates a compelling vision of what air travel could be like with Flighty's help. It taps into the aspirational aspect of product marketing — people aren't just buying an app — they're buying into the idea of a more relaxed, enjoyable travel experience.\\nFinally, the use of \\\"Your\\\" personalizes the message. This makes it feel like Flighty is offering each individual user their own key to a better travel experience. This personal touch can make the app feel more accessible and relevant to potential users.\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t</description>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t</headline>\\n\\t\\t\\n\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t<headline>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<h1>Like the sales assistant your team never had</h1>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<description>\\nFolk's marketing headline \\\"Like the sales assistant your team never had\\\" is a relatable situation and pitch.\\nBeginning the H1 with \\\"Like\\\" creates an immediate analogy that helps users understand Folk's core function. It frames the tool in human terms rather than technical features, making its value more relatable.\\nBy referencing \\\"sales assistant,\\\" the headline clearly positions Folk as a tool for sales teams while implying it handles administrative or support tasks. This suggests it frees up salespeople to focus on more important work.\\nAKA… spending less time on busy work.\\nEnding the H1 with \\\"Your team never had\\\" implies Folk fills a gap or solves a problem that teams have been experiencing. It suggests the tool provides something missing, addressing an unmet need rather than just improving an existing process.\\nFinally, the headline avoids technical jargon about CRM features or data management. Instead, it focuses on the human role Folk plays in supporting sales teams, making it easier to connect with immediately.\\nOverall, this headline is effective because it positions Folk as a human-like assistant rather than just another sales tool.\\nCome for the CRM, stay for the sales assistant.\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t</description>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t</headline>\\n\\t\\t\\n\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t<headline>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<h1>Payroll, benefits and government bullsh*t for startups</h1>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<description>\\nCentral's headline \\\"Payroll, benefits and government bullsh*t for startups\\\" is a bold and refreshingly honest marketing headline.\\nThe use of \\\"bullsh*t\\\" is deliberately provocative and authentic. It stands out and stops the scroll immediately. It acknowledges what many startup founders and operators truly feel about administrative tasks. They're bullsh*t. This honesty can create an immediate connection with the target audience.\\nBy listing \\\"Payroll, benefits and government\\\" before the expletive, the headline establishes credibility first before adding personality. This structure shows they understand the serious nature of these services while empathizing with their customers' frustrations.\\nTargeting \\\"for startups\\\" immediately identifies their core audience. There's no confusion here.\\nThis headline is effective because it strikes a delicate balance between professionalism and personality. It clearly communicates what Central does while using language that resonates with their target audience. The bold word choice makes the headline memorable and helps position Central as a company that understands startup culture and pain points.\\nHowever, like any headline using strong or edgy language, it does risk alienating some potential customers who might prefer more traditional corporate communication.\\nPros and cons… but in this case the pros likely outweigh the cons.\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t</description>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t</headline>\\n\\t\\t\\n\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t<headline>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<h1>A discovery engine for creatives</h1>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<description>\\nCosmos's headline \\\"A discovery engine for creatives\\\" is a thought provoking headline that subtly addresses a common challenge for creatives – finding new ideas or inspirations. This works for a few reasons.\\nThe term \\\"discovery engine\\\" is novel and intriguing. It suggests that Cosmos is more than just a search tool – it's a system designed to uncover new and unexpected things. This phrasing elevates the product beyond a simple database or search engine.\\nBy specifically targeting creatives (one of their target markets cycled through) the headline immediately identifies and appeals to its core audience. This focus helps creatives quickly recognize that Cosmos is a tool designed with their needs in mind.\\nThe headline taps into the constant need for fresh inspiration and new ideas in creative fields. By positioning itself as a discovery tool, Cosmos aligns with the creative process of finding unexpected connections and inspiration.\\nThere's an implied promise of serendipity and surprise in this headline. For creatives who often seek out new inspirations and unconventional ideas, this suggestion of discovery is particularly appealing.\\nOverall, this is a thought provoking headline that leaves a potential user wanting more.\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t</description>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t</headline>\\n\\t\\t</headline-examples>\\n   </headline-examples>\\n\\n   Do not use words from the banlist.\\n   <banlist>\\n   Bustling,\\nHarnessing,\\nUnveiling the power,\\nRealm,\\nDepicted,\\nDemistify,\\nInsurmountable,\\nNew Era,\\nPoised,\\nUnravel,\\nEntanglement,\\nUnprecedented,\\nEerie connection,\\nunliving,\\nBeacon,\\nUnleash,\\nDelve,\\nEnrich,\\nMultifaced,\\nElevate,\\nDiscover,\\nSupercharge,\\nUnlock,\\nUnleash,\\nTailored,\\nElegant,\\nDelve,\\nDive,\\nEver-evolving,\\npride,\\nRealm,\\nMeticulously,\\nGrappling,\\nWeighing,\\nPicture,\\nArchitect,\\nAdventure,\\nJourney,\\nEmbark,\\nNavigate,\\nNavigation,\\ndazzle,\\ntapestry,\\nRevolutionize,\\naugmented reality,\\nAR\\n   </banlist>\\n\\n  </writing_guide>\\n\\n## Mockup Tool\\n\\nYou are provided with a mockup tool which can be used to generate mockups to be used in images for the website.\\n\\nYou should always try to mix and match regular customer images with mockups so the site is always interesting and you break the pattern.\\n\\nThe mockup tool can currently generate the following mockups:\\n- airport-screen\\nThis mockup is a mockup of the company name and logo with a customer image inside an airport billboard.\\nThis is best used in a hero section of an about page or careers page.\\n\\n- dark-screen\\nThis mockup is a mockup of the company name and logo with a dark accent color background on a dark conference room screen\\nThis is best used in a hero section of an about page or careers page but of a dark mode website since this mockup is super dark, and will be too distracting on a light mode website.\\n\\n\\nMake sure to not use the same mockup in different places.\\n\\nRemember - you dont HAVE to always use the mockup tool, but you have the option to use it if you think it will help you create a better website and tel the story better.\\n\\n\\nYou will also be given a hero style for the hero section of the home page.\\nIf you're given a hero style which has left aligned or center aligned text, you need to use the correct hero and pass the prop (centered) correctly.\\n\\n- Make sure to use the correct hero style and import it and not hallucinate it.\\n- If in doubt, just use the default hero, or else use the ask_questions_to_codebase tool to ask the user for help.\\n- Always read the hero file to understand the props and how to use it correctly (centered, title, subtitle, image, testimonials, etc)\\n\\n## Company context\\nYou are building websites specifically for:\\n<company_context>\\nCompany name:\\nProbook AI\\n\\nWhat does the company do, in one sentence? (For example, X makes heavy machinery autonomous. X is building a mobile app for ... to help them with ...)\\nProbook AI provides an AI-powered dispatching solution for home services companies to optimize technician assignments, increase sales and efficiency, and improve customer service.\\n\\nWhich audiences does this company serve:\\nHome services companies, specifically those with service technicians and dispatchers, such as HVAC, plumbing, sewer, and electrical companies.\\n\\nWho founded the company:\\nThe CEO of Probook is mentioned as personally supporting dispatchers during the in-person launch, and George Eliadis is listed in the Calendly booking links, suggesting he is involved, potentially the CEO.\\n\\nOther important facts about the company, if mentioned (such as headquarters location, year founded, funding status, notable milestones, or any distinguishing features):\\nProbook offers a 2-day in-person launch process where their CEO personally supports dispatchers. They offer two levels of automation: Copilot and Autopilot. They integrate with ServiceTitan in real-time. They provide customer service with a 3-minute median response time, 25-minute median resolution time, and 100% post-resolution satisfaction. They are official partners with Nexstar and ServiceTitan.\\n\\nDetailed descriptions of the company's business model, products, services, and market positioning:\\nProbook AI offers an AI-powered dispatching solution designed to optimize the assignment of service technicians to jobs for home services companies. Their core product focuses on using data and AI to make dispatching decisions that maximize revenue, increase efficiency, and improve customer satisfaction.\\n\\nTheir product is offered in two tiers:\\n1.  **Copilot:** This level provides \\\"right-tech, right-call\\\" recommendations at the click of a button. It syncs in real-time with ServiceTitan and keeps dispatchers informed with recommendations.\\n2.  **Autopilot:** This is a more automated solution that fully reshuffles the dispatch board in real-time. Dispatchers remain engaged by verifying job parameters, and this level allows a single dispatcher to manage 20-25+ technicians.\\n\\nProbook's services include:\\n-   AI-driven dispatching decisions based on precise historical data and drive time calculations.\\n-   Maximizing revenue by profitably trading off driving time with expected sales performance.\\n-   Minimizing driving time where possible.\\n-   Providing data-backed insights into technician performance, including sales (repair and TGL), flip rates, and speed (job duration).\\n-   Offering geographical insights, such as average revenue and job count by zip code, and how specific job types perform in different areas.\\n-   Providing a 7-day call board view with real-time integration with ServiceTitan.\\n-   Offering proactive late alerts to inform customers early.\\n-   Providing reschedule recommendations for calls that shouldn't be run when over capacity.\\n-   Improving dispatcher efficiency, allowing them to manage more technicians and freeing up time for customer service.\\n-   Accelerating the training of new dispatchers.\\n-   Providing in-person launch support, including the CEO flying out to personally support dispatchers.\\n-   Offering ongoing support with twice-weekly meetings and 24/7 on-call availability via internal communication channels.\\n\\nProbook positions itself as the premiere AI dispatching solution built by dispatchers, for dispatchers, emphasizing ease of use, trust in decisions, and continuous feature development. They highlight their ability to deliver significant growth in sales, flip rates, and dispatcher efficiency, even for companies already dispatching for profit.\\n\\nClearly identified founders, team They may have large service areas or a significant number of technicians to manage.\\n-   **Goals:** Companies looking to increase sales and average ticket values, improve flip rates (conversion of leads to sales/installs), enhance dispatcher efficiency, reduce driving time, improve customer service through better time management and communication, and standardize their dispatching operations.\\n-   **Technology Adoption:** Companies open to adopting AI-driven software to improve their operations and willing to integrate with existing systems like ServiceTitan.\\n-   **Size:** Based on the customer examples (TR Miller has 40 technicians), Probook is suitable for companies with a moderate to large number of service technicians. The ability to manage 20-25+ techs with a single dispatcher using Autopilot suggests they target companies with a significant dispatching workload.\\n-   **Existing Practices:** Companies that may already be attempting to dispatch for profit but are looking for a more precise, data-backed, and efficient solution.\\n\\nIn essence, Probook targets established home services businesses that are looking to move beyond manual or intuition-based dispatching to a data-driven, optimized approach to drive significant improvements in revenue, efficiency, and customer satisfaction.\\n</company_context>\\n\\n\\nBe sure to remove ANY 'generating' props once you are done updating a component.\\n- ABSOLUTELY NEVER FORGET TO REMOVE THE GENERATING PROPS.\\n\"},{\"role\":\"user\",\"content\":\"<instructions>Update the pricing plans section to fit the company. Image filenames and prompts are saved to './static/generated/index.json' for future reference.\\n\\nAspect Ratio Guidelines:\\n- Testimonials: 3:4\\n- Hero: 16:9\\n- Feature Section: 16:9\\n- CTA Section: 3:4\\n\\nDefault:\\n- When in doubt, use the 16:9 aspect ratio.\\n\\nNote:\\n- If a user requests an image for a specific section or component, add it accordingly.\",\"parameters\":{\"type\":\"object\",\"properties\":{\"images\":{\"type\":\"array\",\"items\":{\"type\":\"object\",\"properties\":{\"aspectRatio\":{\"type\":\"string\",\"enum\":[\"1:1\",\"9:16\",\"16:9\",\"3:4\",\"4:3\"],\"description\":\"Aspect ratio of the image\"},\"prompt\":{\"type\":\"string\",\"description\":\"Prompt for the image generation. Keep the prompt simple and short, like 10 words to allow creative freedom for the model. Never ever show any sort of screens or text in the images. This means no posters, no name tags, no brand names, nothing. Always avoid any sort of futuristic tech, or screens. Even books in general are a no-no.
